abstractContent.text: We propose an apparently minor extension to Kay's (1985} notation for describing directed acyclic graphs (DAGs}.

The proposed notation permits concise descriptions of phenomena which would otherwise be difficult to describe, without incurring significant extra computational overheads in the process of unification.
We illustrate the notation with examples from a categorial description of a fragment of English, and discuss the computational properties of unification of DAGs specified in this way.

introductionContent.text: Much recent work on specifying grammars for fragments of natural languages, and on producing computational systems which make use of these grammars, has used partial descriptions of complex feature structures {Gazdar 1988}.

Grammars are specified in terms of partial descriptions of syntactic structures; programs that depend on these grammars perform some variant of unification in order to investigate the relationship between specific strings of words and the syntactic structures permitted by the grammarmis some sentence grammatical, what actually is its syntactic structure, how can some partially specified structure be realised as a string of words, and soon.
